awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Identifying network dynamics promoting memory consolidation during sleep
awd_abstract_narration:
While the exact physiological function of sleep remains unknown, there is mounting evidence that it plays an important role in the consolidation of long-term memories. In particular, it appears that sleep promotes the consolidation of declarative memories that require a functionally intact hippocampus, including memories of place. In rodents, place-dependent fear memory is promoted by sleep and disrupted by sleep deprivation. Sleep deprivation also disrupts a number biochemical and neurophysiological processes that are thought to be involved in memory consolidation. These studies have led many to suggest that sleep promotes long-term memory consolidation by modulating neural network dynamics and synaptic plasticity within the hippocampus. In experimental studies, the co-PIs have recently identified changes in hippocampal neural network dynamics during sleep that are induced by place-dependent fear learning.  In computational modeling studies, the co-PIs have shown that acetylcholine, a modulatory chemical whose levels vary across sleep states, can change neural network dynamics in a similar way. The proposed projects take a multidisciplinary, multi-scale approach to bridge the gap between experimental and computational results, to identify how effects of acetylcholine on neurons lead to changes in neural network dynamics to promote learning, ultimately leading to learning and memory behavior. While the focus is on fear learning and memory consolidation, the fundamental knowledge of learning-related and sleep-related brain network dynamics gained by the proposed experiments and computations will provide valuable insights into mechanisms for all types of learning.

At present, it is unclear how sleep-related changes in hippocampal network dynamics might promote contextual fear memory  consolidation. The team's recent experimental studies have shown that contextual fear conditioning produces long-lasting, sleep-dependent increases in the stability of hippocampal network functional connectivity patterns. These results, coupled with the team's recent computational studies describing a role for acetylcholine in network-wide activity and synaptic plasticity patterning, have led to the hypothesis that sleep promotes memory consolidation, at least in part, by dynamically shifting patterns in hippocampal neural network activity during naturally-occurring rapid eye movement and slow wave sleep brain states. Sleep-dependent acetylcholine has a primary role in driving these shifts in network activity through its effects on cellular excitability properties.   The proposed projects use behavioral, physiological, and computational approaches to tackle the missing links that will show the hypothesized network mechanisms occur in brain hippocampal networks and participate in fear learning and memory.  Hippocampal acetylcholine levels will be manipulated across wake and sleep states while recording multi-unit activity in hippocampus to quantify changes in spike timing dynamics in the context of fear and subsequent sleep or sleep deprivation. The team has developed a suite of quantitative measures to identify learning-related changes in network dynamics.  In addition, acetylcholine-induced changes in cellular membrane properties that affect network dynamics will be measured in hippocampal pyramidal cell and inhibitory interneuron populations. The results will be used to inform details of biophysical neural network models to identify specific dynamical mechanisms by which acetylcholine-mediated changes in network activity dynamics promote network stability, structural changes and synaptic reorganization associated with learning and consolidation.

por.por_cntn:
Acetylcholine (ACh) is one of the most powerful modulators of brain activity. It has been implicated in contributing to diverse cognitive processes including attention, motivation, learning and memory. In cortical and hippocampal brain regions, ACh affects neuron response properties as well as modifying synaptic efficacy. The goal of the grant projects was to connect ACh-mediated changes in neuron properties to network-wide neuron spiking activity and subsequent behavior through multidisciplinary projects involving experimental studies and computational modeling.  

 

One set of experimental studies focused on characterizing ACh effects on single neurons such as changes in frequency-current responses and phase response curves. Computational modeling results identified that these ACh-induced changes in cellular response properties can change the way that information is encoded in a neural network. Rate coding and phase coding are the two major coding modes seen in the brain. Neural network dynamics support these codes by having a wide distribution of frequencies for rate coding, or, for phase coding, a narrow one to achieve stability in phase relationships. ACh modulation of cellular properties is capable of changing the distribution of neural firing rates to support either of these coding modes.  Through analysis of biophysically based neural network models that simulate K+ based M-current modulation by ACh, results have shown that the ACh-induced transition in cellular excitability facilitates a dynamic switch between rate coding and phase coding as levels of ACh change. While there are examples of rate coding and phase coding existing in the same neural circuits, these results showing a primary role of ACh in facilitating transitions in coding schemes is novel.  These results have potentially transformative implications regarding how information is coded and transmitted across brain circuits during wake and sleep states as a result of ACh up- or down-regulation.

 

Another set of experiments set out to test how ACh-induced changes in brain network activity contributed to learning and memory consolidation of a fear conditioning task in rodents. Using chemogenetic techniques to selectively inhibit specific neuron types and selectively activate ACh expression in the hippocampus, preliminary experiments investigated how disrupting network activity and the normal change of ACh expression across sleep and wake states led to deficits in memory consolidation. 

 

Neuromodulation of cortical regions by acetylcholine has traditionally been assumed to be temporally slow and spatially diffuse. Recent experiments indicate, however, that cholinergic signaling is temporally fast and spatially localized in the prefrontal cortex in the context of attentional performance tasks. Additionally, in this context cholinergic transients generated theta-modulated gamma frequency neural firing patterns that contributed to successful performance of an attentional behavioral task. Computational modeling results analyzed the impact of spatial heterogeneity of cholinergic signalling in a biophysical cortical neural network model. With network connectivity of local excitation and global inhibition, model results demonstrated that spatially localized ACh modulation is a plausible mechanism for theta-gamma coupled neural spiking patterns. Specifically, stable gamma band firing emerged in the centers of high ACh signaling sites, with theta band or mixed theta-gamma band firing occurring at the peripheries. Moreover, gamma activity alternated between distinct high ACh sites at theta band frequency. Model analysis showed that theta-gamma coupling was sensitive to the local excitation/global inhibition network connectivity and to the level and spatial distribution of ACh modulated sites. These results are the first to provide a link between the spatial distribution of ACh and theta-gamma rhythmicity. 

 

Computational modeling studies additionally investigated the interaction of the effects of anesthetics and ACh on neural activity. There is wide-spread evidence that anesthetics have long-lasting effects on cognitive processing and learning, especially in cognitively vulnerable patients such as the elderly. Recent experiments have suggested that interventions that promote cholinergic actions in cortical regions can promote faster recovery from anesthesia as well as reverse the effects of anesthesia. These animal-based studies rely on behavioral measures of the effects of anesthesia such as apparent loss of consciousness and loss of righting reflex. Questions remain as to whether induced cholinergic actions restore neural activity patterns to pre-anesthesia levels. Grant projects investigated this question using biophysical neural network models to simulate the effects of the inhalational anesthetic desflurane, comparing model network spiking dynamics to those measured in vivo in the visual cortex, and predicting the recovery of spiking activity due to simulated cholinergic actions. Model results showed that the neuronal effects of ACh modulation could successfully restore network firing activity from the effects on synaptic efficacies caused by the anesthetic. These results provide the first hypothesis for how ACh can reverse anesthetic effects as observed behaviorally.

 

Grant projects provided training in interdisciplinary computational neuroscience for 5 graduate students (4 PhD students (2 in neuroscience, 1 in Physics, 1 in Applied Physics) and 1 MS student (in applied mathematics)).
